Oct. 3rd, 1868

To J. D. McLean Esq.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith an account of the Indian schools of Huron, Brant, and Pelee. Under separate headings I have given the schools visited, as far as possible, a brief account of what I have seen and found them to be doing. I am glad to note that during my visits to these schools, being made at the commencement of the school term, I found that all children had returned from their studies after the long vacation. I felt it would be useless to do more than tell you that the teachers had the children properly classified.

In the report sent in, you will notice that the Red Ground school was omitted, and the reason is this: Since last school term, the school was closed due to the absence of the teacher and the teacher, in consequence, is obliged to help his children in one of the homes of the Indians.

Sir;

In re. No. 119215/1.

In reply to your letter of enquiry in re. Miss Mary Isaacs, Teacher of the Eel Ground Indian School, Eel Ground, Northumberland Co., I may say, that she took charge of this school on the Sixth day of January last. As to her experience she has been teaching Fourteen years, and holds an Elementary Diploma from Carleton Convent, of the Province of Quebec. She has taught English, French and Micmac, also Music, Singing and Knitting. She was Thirty-one years of age on the Twenty-second day of February last.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Ottawa, December 7th, 1909.

Sir,

In view of the fact that Miss Isaacs, who has been in charge of the Eel Ground School since January last, has recently married it will be necessary to secure the services of a new teacher for this school to take charge, if possible, after the Christmas holidays. The Department desires to obtain a fully qualified teacher and will be prepared to pay a reasonable salary for such. I have to ask you, therefore, to make inquiries with a view to securing a teacher and any applications that you receive should be forwarded to the Department for its consideration. Great care should be taken in the selection of a teacher for this and other Indian schools if the results hoped for by the Department are to be achieved! On no account should any appointment be made by you until the consent of the Department is obtained. The Superintendent of Schools for New Brunswick is also being communicated with in connection with this matter.

Miss Isaacs should be notified that her services will not be required after the end of this quarter, but in the event of the Department not being able to secure a teacher it would be glad if she would consent to take charge of this school for a time next term. Be good enough to acknowledge the receipt of this letter at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

R. A. Irving, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
Buctouche, N.B.

Secretary.
Ottawa, December 7th, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your report on the Bel Ground School, and in reference thereto I beg to say that the Department has decided to dispense with the services of Miss Isaacs at the end of this quarter and she will be so advised through the Indian Superintendent.

The Department desires to obtain for this school the services of a qualified teacher and I should be glad if you would make inquiries with a view to securing such. Mr. Irving has been asked to make similar inquiries. Any applications received by you should be submitted to the Department for its consideration.

I may also add that the new out-houses have been provided at this school and the account for the same has been received.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

R. A. Irving Esq., Bemidji No. 13.

Sir:

I am just in receipt of your letter of 27th ult., and in reply thereof I say that I wrote to Mr. Wapfley shortly after you were granted a patent for the school, just to make him aware of my application for the same.

The question of the Self-Government School is a delicate matter, for it will have to antagonize the Indians and the Indians are not very anxious to see the school succeed. In fact, they seem to be opposed to the wishes of the Indians.

I shall wait for a few days longer in the hope of hearing from Mr. Wapfley and if I hear still let you know what he says in the matter. We may then be able to decide what it is best to do.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Rev. Father Ryan,
St. Mary's Ferry, N.B.

Reverend Dear Sir;—

I have not as yet heard from you in reference to the School Teacher of the "Bel Ground Reserve," Northumberland County, N.B. You will remember that I informed you that Miss Mary Isaacs the present Teacher, had resigned and that Miss Francis Schulte who was in charge of the School previous to Miss Isaacs appointment, was endeavouring to again secure the appointment as Teacher of that School. I have received a petition from the Chief and 23 members of the Band, asking that Miss Maggie Isaacs, sister of the present teacher, Miss Mary Isaacs, be engaged. They do not want Miss Schulte and when I decided to make a change some time ago, and had Miss Schulte displaced by Miss Isaacs, I did so in the interest of the Indian education among the members of the band. You promised me to write Father Duffy in reference to the matter and I would like for you to advise me under the circumstances as to what you would recommend being done.

Thanking you in advance, I remain,

Yours very truly,

(Signed) R. A. IRVING,
Indian Supt.

Dear Sir,

We understand that Miss Emma Shultz is undertaking to get into the school on the reserve as teacher you are aware she taught there before and it did not suit. We have engaged Miss Maggie Isaac to take the school after it goes as the present teacher has tendered her resignation to close on the 30th June. Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter number 119215/1 dated December 7th, 1909 in re. a Teacher for the "Bel Ground School" and in reply I may say, that the present Teacher, Miss Mary Isaacs, has tendered her resignation as Teacher of this School, to take effect at the close of this term. Some short time after the receipt of her resignation I interviewed Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, and informed him of the above resignation and also told him that I had received a petition from some of the members of the Band, asking that Miss Maggie Isaacs, a sister of the present Teacher, who holds a Diploma or similar qualification to that of the present Teacher, be engaged to take the school next term. Miss Schulz who was Teacher of this school previous to Miss Isaacs engagement, has I understand been endeavouring to again get the appointment as Teacher, although she has made no direct application to me, but, you will notice by the petition and a letter from the Chief, which are both herewith enclosed, that some of the members of the Band are not in favour of giving the School to her. When I spoke to Father Ryan, he promised that he would write Father Duffy the Clergyman in charge of the reservation, and get his opinion upon the matter. Not hearing from Father Ryan I wrote him on the 27th., of November last, a copy of which letter I herewith enclose, and I did on the 7th., of December Instant, receive from Father Ryan a reply to my letter, which is also

In your letter of the 7th inst., No. 1192/5, you ask me to make inquiries in connection with Mr. Irving, Jr., a teacher for the school at El Dorado, to place his name on the coming term list. I may say I have had some talks and some correspondence with Mr. Irving about a teacher for his school, but as much as I have heard and know, as well as others, we try to have his school, a home teacher restored to its position. Mr. Smith taught at El Dorado following at the Johnson's (or) Bishop's School. While Mr. Irving's name is only mentioned in our catalogue, no one else has heard of him. If you should be interested, I would be glad to put him down in his case.

I am as yet but half convinced in the sincerity of my friend. Others, among her friends, who were teaching in the chief's house at a considerable distance from the chief of the Assiniboins, and probably owing to these two facts, her attendance was very small. They were but 5 children present.

She had no accommodation—no means to blackboards—in fact, her room was not fitted out. She stated in the report of his school which I sent to the Inspector, that she said if any dormitory were set up that would change conditions she would willingly do better.

Ottawa, December 23rd, 1909.

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant in reference to the appointment of a teacher for the Bel Ground School, and in reply I beg to say that the contents have been carefully noted.

There are now three applicants for this position, Miss Schultz, Miss Maggie Isaacs and Miss Laura C. Geraghty. The Department would like to have any testimonials that Miss Geraghty has in her possession, and Mr. Irvin, the Indian Superintendent, has been asked to forward certificates and testimonials from Miss Isaacs. Although Miss Schultz was in charge of this school for sometime the Department has no official report of inspection on record. It would, therefore, like to have full information with reference to her age, certificates, etc., and copies of her testimonials also.

The Department is desirous of obtaining the services of the best teacher possible for this school and when all the information asked for in reference to these applications is laid before it a decision will be arrived at. In the meantime it is presumed that the present teacher, Miss Mary Isaacs, will remain in charge till her successor is appointed. You will be good enough to see, therefore, that the testimonials, etc., from Miss Schultz and Miss Geraghty are forwarded at the earliest possible date.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. J. J. Ryan,
Superintendent of Indian Schools,
St. Mary's Ferry, N.B.

Sir,

Referring to official letter of the 15th instant in reference to the application of Miss Maggie Isaacs for the position of teacher of the Bel Ground School I beg to say that no appointment is to be made to fill this vacancy except by the Department. In the past some changes have been made without the concurrence of the Department, which reserves to itself the right to dismiss and appoint teachers of Indian schools.

The Department is awaiting the application from Miss Isaacs with the information called for in the letter above referred.

Your obedient servant,

Secretary.

Ottawa, December 28th, 1906.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant enclosing four applications for the position of teacher of the Nel Ground Indian school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department cannot deal with these applications until it is in receipt of testimonials from each of the applicants. In the cases of the applications of Miss Schultz and Miss Muzerell the certificates held are not stated and in each instance the Department should also be advised as to the age. Full information with reference to these applications was given you in letter of the 23rd instant. It is also noted that no application is forwarded by Miss Garaghty to whom reference was made by Mr. Superintendent Ryan in his letter of the 16th instant.

In two of the applications received reference was made to an advertisement inserted by you in the Advocate. This action should not have been taken without authority from the Department, and you will be good enough to advise at once as to what salary you offered in that advertisement.

Further and full information will be awaited before a decision is arrived at.

Your obedient servant,

The Department has received eight applications for the position of teacher of the Eel Ground School, but, as the services of one of the applicants, Miss Laura C. Geraghty, will not be available until after next summer holidays, only seven of them have to be considered. The names of the applicants are as follows:

Two petitions have been received from the Indians, one signed by the Chief and 26 members of the Band asking for the appointment of Miss Isaac; and the other signed by 13 Indians and 22 others, presumably whites, including the Parish Priest, asking for the reinstatement of Miss Schultz.

Other things being equal it would appear politic to try to please the Indians in making this appointment; hence I think we should consider only the applications of Miss Isaac and Miss Schultz.

Miss Schultz previously taught this school for nearly three years and was dismissed by Mr. Superintendent Irving.
Irving without the authority of the Department, acting, as he considered, in the best interests of the Indians. Miss Schultz worked under a great disadvantage while at this school. The school was held in an Indian's house not centrally located; now they have a new school with modern equipment. But the fact remains that she holds no certificate and her success is at best problematical.

On the other hand Miss Isaac, who has the support of the larger number of Indians, has been in charge of the Maria school for 4½ years. Her record there has been good and she would in all probability be still in charge of that school had it not been for the unfortunate friction which arose between Rev. J. D. Morin, our Agent, and herself. Miss Isaac holds an Elementary Diploma (Quebec) and understands the Micmac language. I quote from Mr. School Inspector Marquis' last report on her work at Maria as follows:

"In short, I am strongly convinced that the teacher, Miss Margaret Isaac, whose mother tongue is Micmac but who speaks English and French equally well, performs the task that is entrusted to her with confidence and devotion and the pupils of this school receive careful education and instruction."

I am strongly of opinion that the best interests of the Indians would be served by the appointment of Miss Isaac. One essential to success is their good-will, and evidently the Chief and his followers would be antagonized were anyone else appointed.

Of late the Department has been paying a great deal of attention to the betterment of day school conditions in New Brunswick and with an appreciable measure of success. Therefore the appointment of a new teacher at this juncture is one of paramount importance. While the Department is always glad to have the recommendations of members of Parliament in connection with these appointments and, other things
things being equal, to appoint their nominees, the interests of the school should receive the first consideration.

In the present instance, in view of the strongly expressed wish of the Chief and Councillors, who are the leaders of their people and whose influence is essential to harmonious and effective work, for the appointment of Miss Isaac, I am afraid that any other course on the part of the Department would nullify any efforts to improve conditions on this reserve, which are not at present what they ought to be.

Of course it would be pleasing to have Mr. Loggie's concurrence in Miss Isaac's appointment, and when the facts are laid before him I have no doubt that he will appreciate the desire for improvement which animates the Department, and be willing to aid in carrying out this policy by agreeing to the appointment of a qualified teacher who has the confidence of the Indians.

Dear Mr. Perrin,

I have just received a letter from Father Ryan, stating that the Eygound Indians, among whom I have been teaching since last Sept., have sent in several complaints against me. Well, that is nothing new, as you are aware; when they wish to dispense with a teacher's services, if they cannot find complaints they'll invent them.

Now Father Ryan said I could have the school again under following conditions:

1. That I could not take my children there now, that includes all, as I live in Mr. Ryan parish. He knows full well and cannot take some of my children, I cannot teach them at all.

I have five children all depending on me for support. The oldest boy nearly 14, is the only one who caused disturbance among the Ind. children. He would not go to the school for English children and he annoyed me considerably by quarrelling.
I had intended sending them to a good school, and taking most with me. One little girl 11, one boy 5, and one other little girl 6, would all be attending the English school, which is 14 miles distant from hereground, and one little boy of four plays around and bothers nobody. So I can promise you, in future my children will not associate with bad children, either in or outside school hours.

Greater care must be given teaching children their prayers etc.

This Mr. Ferrier is where I made a mistake apparently. Every morning and evening I used recite all the common prayers, getting children to respond. In addition I used take nearly an hour every day trying to get them to memorize their catechism. I thought I was spending enough time on religion, as they have a nice church, mass & catechism every second Sunday. My chief aim was to get them to read, spell, and learn arithmetic, and to get them to talk better English, and defy anyone to say I wasn't succeeding. I was trying too hard, and that is why children did not thank
The attempt was too slack with them.

3rdly some guarantee must be given for better attendance.

If they appoint another truant officer, that is sufficient guarantee that the children will attend. The last truant officer was afraid to go to force children to school. Rather than pay the burden of better attendance rests with the teacher. I disagree with him there.

If so, why does government pay a truant officer for work done by teachers? I'll tell you Mr. Reid, I could have a good attendance also, if I let children take charge and do just as they pleased. That is the only way a teacher can have a good attendance in school. I offered prizes for best attendance ground. I offered prizes for best attendance ground. You see result. For the last 3 months I was there, Mr. Reid, truant officer never went near there. Mr. Reid, truant officer never went near there. Children to bring them to school. Mother did she visit school. I asked him why he wasn't doing his duty - he told me "I'm very busy now teacher, haven't time".

4th Domestic Science must be taught with better advantage to all.

It wasn't my fault that the children didn't do
I wrote twice to Mr. Agent Hudson, asking first for yarn, and lastly for some gingham to make dresses etc., but he ignored both letters. Of course I knew the Indians blamed me. Surely the Govt. didn't expect me to buy yarn etc. for Indians out of my own salary. Or I was not authorized to get it, and have it charged to Government.

You and Father Ryan will do as you like about school, but instead of taking my position away from me, and allowing my children to go hungry, the Dominion Government should be giving pensions to poor mothers to keep them raise their families, instead of throwing it at rich men, like Fielding, who do not need it. It is the rich the Govt. helps, not the poor, let them work and pay taxes to pension off old men.

Thanking you for your kindness shown in the past, I beg to remain,

Yours very Truly,
Katherine Shea

If you can obtain another teacher, you should give Miss Murdock notice as soon as possible that her services will not be further required. Please submit the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher whom you are able to obtain for this school to begin duties on or about January 4th, next. We would allow salary at the same rate as was offered Miss Murdock, the amount to depend on whether she teaches domestic science or not. Dear Mr. Territorial,

Miss Sheasgreen—the Provincial nurse was here today and called another day at Belgrand Ind. Reserve.

She reports that the teacher, Miss Sheasgreen did not get to her school until 10 A.M.—this morning. I have not been satisfied with the work in this school, as you will see by my report—This was a very promising teacher and did fair work the first year—but since—my reasons for writing you is this—it would make matters much better, if I received a letter from you, stating that no certain reports have reached the Dept. re this school, that the services of Miss Sheasgreen would be no longer required.

It is a little hard for me as she belongs to my Parish, and to one of my best families—but yet all this counts as nothing to me, when justice is at stake; however, I would like to get around the difficulty with the least trouble as possible.—She made great, and did wonderful when teaching in WHITE SCHOOLS.

and many to come,

Dear Sirs:

You will please find three applications for the Belgrand Ind. day school, as Miss Fitzgerald has accepted a white school near her home, and as these teachers wish to locate a school before resigning their present ones, which must be done this Saturday, explains my hurry in writing, -

(Miss McLean excepted as she is just coming out of Normal school) - she of course would not fill the "BILL."

Of the other two, - You will find that Miss Carmel Hegan has been out teaching for the past three years, and I must here add a girl of great piety who would rather like an Ind. school, -- On the other hand, Miss Murphy is also from this Parish and to my mind not so efficient having but one year's experience - Yet the Dept.'s letter to me setting forth Miss Hegan's appointment should clearly read - that due to Miss Hegan's longer experience, the Dept. has appointed her - by so doing you can help me out of a Parish difficulty. -- I feel that we are most fortunate in being able to secure such a teacher,

She is a sister of Miss Mary Hegan who taught so successfully in our Ind. school at Red Bank and who is now the Principal of the Red Bank white school,

I never thought a Parish Priest could be guilty of POLITICS but when I read this, it almost looks like the color of them.

I do trust that all the boys are well,

Miss Fitzgerald's resignation will follow in a few days.

She was doing great work, but as her mother is dead, she wished to teach at her home school so as to keep open the home for her father & brother & sisters.

F. C. Ryan

In my twenty years of experience with Indian schools I have never seen such progress in any of our N. B. Indian schools as was shown in this school. Dear Sir:

It certainly is a grave experiment in higher education, again the way it comes about, by parents on its side in their own crafty way, influencing their children of 14 to act in such a way that the teacher must send the pupil home.

Something must be done, and done at once to curb this all too common situation; the child is not to blame, so is the lazy indifferent parent who wants to run the roads and loaf, thus when their children just get interested in higher education, around 14 years, then act at once within a week or a few days a most obedient child become unmanageable in the school.

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am attaching hereto, for your information, copies of correspondence relating to a brutal assault on Miss Delphine Murphy, teacher of the Bel Ground Indian day school, (Northumberland Electoral District) New Brunswick.

In view of this regrettable incident, it is just possible that we should undertake immediately a survey of our Indian reserves, particularly our reserves in eastern Canada, in an attempt to determine the adequacy of the police protection provided at these centres. The Superintendent of Welfare and Training has on more than one occasion referred to the inadequacy of the police protection at the Caughnawaga reserve, Quebec.

The Bel Ground reserve has an Indian population of 173 (1934 census). The Indian population of this reserve have been for a number of years in receipt of relief allowances. A part time Indian constable is employed and receives remuneration at the rate of $70.0 per annum.

Dear Father Ryan:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 15th instant, in which you refer to the brutal assault on Miss Delphine Murphy, teacher of the Eel Ground Indian day school.

The Director of this Branch has this morning sent forward, with a covering memorandum, a copy of your letter to the office of the Minister.

I have never been wholly satisfied with the police protection provided on Indian reserves, particularly Indian reserves in eastern Canada. It is my earnest hope, therefore, that this most regrettable incident may effect a change of policy and result in the government extending a greater measure of protection to Indian agents and particularly to Indian day school teachers employed on Indian reserves throughout the country.

I have just learned from the agent that the Royal Canadian Mounted Police have charge of the case. It is my hope that no stone will be left unturned until the party or parties responsible have been adequately punished for this brutal assault.

If these Indians cannot find work on reserves, they should be placed on farms or at work outside the reserves in return for their relief allowances. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

I am in receipt of Mr. Jackson's memorandum of July 12, enclosing the attached correspondence with reference to the assault on Miss P. Murphy, teacher of the Bel Ground Indian Day School, near Newcastle, N. B.

In connection with this matter I would refer you to my memorandum of May 20, to which was attached copies of correspondence relating to the assault on Miss Murphy.

As you will note from Indian Agent Hudson's letter of May 16, a copy of which was forwarded with my memorandum of May 20, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police took charge of the case immediately and we have received from them reports dated as follows: May 20, May 26, May 30, June 8 and July 1. The last report reads as follows:

"Further re the above case, please be advised that to-date no further information has been received. Miss MURPHY is still in the hospital, her condition is good and it is expected that she will be discharged from the hospital soon. However, she cannot remember anything more about the assault.

"At the present time Madam Paul, Indian from Burnt Church Reserve, is living on Bel Ground Reserve and it is hoped that she may be able to obtain information.

"An extension of the diary date is requested to July 15th."

I think -
I think you will agree with me that Reverend Father Ryan is not fair to this Branch when he intimates in his letters that no action has been taken. We are not responsible for prosecution of offences under the Criminal Code and you will note from the dates of the reports received from the R.C.M.P. that they have been working on the matter steadily but apparently have not yet obtained sufficient evidence to permit them to lay a charge.

I may add that Miss Murphy has been allowed her full salary to June 30, 1940, on which date the school would have ordinarily closed for the summer holidays.

Director.

Mr. Sir,

I am writing you in regard to the change of teachers in the Indian Day Schools at El Ground, Burnt Church and Cromocto.

Rev. Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, asked me to take El Ground School.

Recently it was suggested that Miss Murphy and Miss Hogan teachers at Cromocto and Burnt Church respectively, were to exchange schools owing to the condition of Miss Murphy's health.

Miss Hogan did not want Cromocto School and tried to get El Ground School.

As far as I can ascertain...
they came to Rev. Father Ryan with their plan and he said they could not make the change at Eel Ground unless I was willing. I have not consented that I was willing and in spite of the fact, they arranged a letter and had it forwarded to the Department stating that all concerned were willing to make the change, and evidently when Rev. Father Ryan received the letter he thought they had talked the matter over with me and as far as I know Miss Hogan wrote to the Department stating that I was willing to go to Portobello which was false.

If it was proposed that Miss Murphy was to exchange schools with Miss Hogan why should Miss Hogan have the right to interfere with Eel Ground School and acquire it by false statements.

If I lost my school through inefficiency, lack of teaching ability or neglect of duty, it would be a different proposition, but such is not the case, as for
as I can determine it was brought about by Miss Hogan.

All was done and published in the local paper that I was to take Oronoeto School before I knew about it.

If you are doubtful about the truth of anything that I have written, you are at liberty to consult Rev. Father Ryan.

It does not seem fair that Miss Hogan should have the right to take Col Ground School from me where I was having no trouble with the Indian children and propose that I take Oronoeto School simply to comply with her wishes.

Will you kindly give the matter consideration and let me know immediately what you can do for me in respect to my keeping Col Ground School next term.

Yours truly,

M. Helen Lawlor.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report dated December 10, 1940, relating to the above noted subject and signed by K. Duncan, Superintendent and Assistant Director, Criminal Investigation Branch, Royal Canadian Mounted Police.

Mr. Duncan sends forward with his report additional reports received by him from Corporal R. A. Stewart and W. V. Bruce, Superintendent, Commanding "J" Division. It is noted that in both these reports a reference is made to relief costs at the Bel Ground Reserve and a misunderstanding seems to exist with respect to the source or appropriation from which relief expenditures are made. Corporal Stewart states:

"I might add that nearly every Indian questioned regarding this case made reference to the question of relief to the Indian families being stopped because of Indian children remaining away from school. This was particularly noticed when talking to the better educated members of the tribe, several remarking the relief they obtained came from moneys placed in a fund for their benefit when the treaty was made, and they considered neither the teacher nor the Indian agent had any right to deprive them of what was rightfully theirs."

Superintendent Bruce States:

"This report discloses what was probably the real reason for the assault of Miss Murphy. Insofar as we have been able to ascertain, the

Mr. Charles Hudson,

Indians -
Indians have in a trust fund administered by the Government a sum of money which accumulates in various ways and which the Indians regard as their own property. This fund is used in part to supply relief to the Indians when they need it.

It is in the judgment of the Department very disturbing that this misunderstanding has arisen with respect to relief expenditures. A statement was sent to you immediately following the close of the last fiscal year. This statement dealt very fully and in detail with the Indian trust funds of your agency. You must be fully aware that relief costs have not been paid from Indian trust funds at any time, certainly not at any time in recent years. In the case of the Bel Ground Band, their trust funds at this date amount to approximately $3,182.59 capital and $1,166.33 interest. The total expenditures for the last fiscal year made from this trust fund amounted to $4.35.

The Department is anxious to know what steps have been taken by you from year to year to explain to the Indians concerned the standing of their trust funds, the expenditures made from these funds, the amount of annual interest allowed on such trust funds and such other information as might appear to the Indians or to you relevant to the subject.

We are anxious that you should acknowledge receipt of this letter and state what steps you intend to take to clear up this particular misunderstanding and any other misunderstanding that may exist in respect to Indian trust funds. You may note in the excerpt from Corporal Stewart a reference to a treaty. It would be interesting to know just what treaty the Indians had in mind when discussing this subject with Corporal Stewart. We have reminded Indian agents from time to time that relief is not the right of any Indian and that relief is extended from time to time, particularly to the old and physically incapacitated, not in fulfillment of any treaty obligations or not as something
that the Indians may demand, but to avoid suffering and hardship. The Department reserves the right to withhold this relief at any time in the case of able-bodied men who, with economic conditions gradually improving, should be in a position to become increasingly self-supporting.

Dear Miss Murphy:

Your telegram of January 6, addressed to the Right Honourable the Prime Minister, has been passed on to this Division for consideration and reply.

It is not customary for officials in the field or for teachers in charge of our Indian day or residential schools to communicate direct with the Prime Minister and in a period as critical as the one in which we now find ourselves you will readily appreciate the desirability of not encroaching upon the Prime Minister's time or the time of any of the Ministers, in fact, with respect to matters that can be adjusted by the senior officials of the Department.

I find it difficult to understand the first sentence in your telegram, which reads:

"Through a misunderstanding I am deprived of my school at Eel Ground".

The records here indicate that you were transferred from Eel Ground at your own request. In a letter to the Minister, signed by you and dated September 18, 1940, you state:

"After an experience such as mine, you will readily see that I dread going to an unfamiliar district such as Eel River. The doctor tells me that it is imperative that I avoid anxiety, so that I feel it imprudent to venture into this isolated district".

In response to instructions received by this Division from the Minister at that time, your case was very thoroughly and very sympathetically investigated, with the result that you were transferred to Oromocto, in the hope that you could find conditions there conducive to your recovery and satisfactory in every sense. I feel that it is only fair to the Minister and to the officials here to state that tremendous pressure was brought to bear upon him to have you removed from Oromocto and to have Miss Scott reinstated. Time and again, however, the Minister resisted these appeals, prompted by a desire to help you to the utmost extent possible. The changes now under consideration were suggested by Father Ryan and were based on the assumption that all these changes were satisfactory to the teachers concerned. It now transpires that just the reverse is the case: they do not appear

Miss Delphine Murphy,
Newcastle,
New Brunswick.
to be satisfactory to anybody. I would suppose, however, that individuals have the right to change their mind, even though such change may prove very inconvenient to the Department.

I have very carefully reviewed the correspondence relating to your employment at Eel Ground and your transfer therefrom, including the voluminous reports received from the R. C. M. P., and I am personally of the opinion that it is a mistake for you to report at Eel Ground for duty. I make this statement having had almost 20 years' experience in the administration of public schools and Indian schools and knowing something about incidents such as the unfortunate incident in which you yourself were involved. Despite this fact, however, and in response to your own request and on the recommendation of Father Ryan, you will be permitted to return to the Eel Ground School and to take charge of that school immediately following the holiday period that has been allowed you. However, the Inspector and I must assume full responsibility for this change. You were transferred from Eel Ground at your own request and you are being returned at your own request. Transfers of teachers at Indian day schools are only authorized in very urgent cases and it is scarcely necessary to add that it is not our intention to continue to transfer teachers from time to time in the province of New Brunswick. In order that there may be no misunderstanding, therefore in the future, I am anxious that you should read this letter very carefully, note its contents and acknowledge receipt of it in due course.

Dear Sir:

Miss Delphine Murphy will take charge of the Eel Ground School on or about February 3.

Miss Murphy is returning to the Eel Ground School at her own request and on the recommendation of the Inspector of Indian Schools, Reverend Father Ryan. The Police in their reports have suggested that the bodily assault from which Miss Murphy has suffered may have been due in part at least to the reductions that took place in relief allowances, these reductions in some cases having been made on her recommendation. I am anxious that you should discuss this matter with Miss Murphy, immediately following her return to Eel Ground, and following that discussion I am desirous that you should assume full responsibility for the administration of relief on this particular reserve. It is difficult for me to see how a teacher can do her best work and exercise the influence she should exercise if she becomes involved from time to time in relief matters and in the reduction of relief rations. I am of the opinion that the Indian agent, and the Indian agent alone, should modify his relief policy from time to time in a way that will appeal to his own best judgment. It might be advisable, also, to explain to the Indians that you are accepting full responsibility for the administration of relief and that the teacher will be responsible in the future only for the actual classroom work in the school.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,

Dear Sir:

I have been informed by Reverend Father Ryan that my letter of the 23rd ultimo addressed to the Secretary, Mr. MacInnes, has been referred to your attention. In justice to myself I feel that I must write you concerning my request to be given back my former school.

It is no great surprise for me to learn that you cannot understand why I am now willing to return to Eel Ground. I shall try to explain. From the very first it was my intention to go back to my own school as soon as I felt able to teach. My family would not hear of it as there was so much uncertainty about the outcome of the case, and they insisted on a change. I was assured that the school was still mine, and that the teacher named was but substituting until such time as it would be safe to return.

The request of a further change to Burnt Church was made without my consent or approval and wholly for the benefit of Miss Hogan. I could not possibly sleep at Burnt Church surrounded by the relatives of my would-be assassins. As stated in my last letter I have been assured of daily transportation to and from Eel Ground so that I shall feel safe.

I submit to you the above facts and I am disposed to think that you will see fit now to allow me to take up the work again at Eel Ground, and have Miss Hogan resume former duties at Burnt Church. I shall greatly appreciate an early reply as I cannot get the full benefit of my leave of absence until this matter is settled.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir—

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of Jan. 6th, 1941, Pyle #55-3-1, re assault on Miss Delphine Murphy, Bel Ground Reserve, N.B.

In reply, I am sorry that such misunderstandings exist, as for nearly 20 years now, I have been, by oral persuasion, trying to impress the Indians that payment of relief to Indians has not been paid from trust funds. In the case of Bel Ground Reserve, the Indians all know that the cost of relief per year is many times the amount of their trust funds. But in the minds of the Micmac Indians, there is the impression that there is a sum of money in the hands of the Department, which they think is inexhaustible, and was placed there years ago for the use of the Indians, and it is out of this fund that they think all sorts of relief is being paid.

I am quite certain that there is not an Indian on the Bel Ground reserve but who knows that the relief expenditure is not paid out of their trust fund. With regard to what steps I have taken to explain to the Indians, the standing of their trust funds, I have not thought it necessary to make any special statement to them concerning these funds, as the chiefs usually receive the report of the Indian Affairs Branch every year, and are just as familiar with the contents as I am myself.

With regard to what steps I intend to take to clear up this misunderstanding, I don't think there is anything more I can do, as I have repeatedly explained to the Indians that the expense of relief does not come out of their trust funds, and that it is only charity on the part of the Department that they receive relief at all.

With regard to the treaty referred to by Corpl. Stewart, I will try to procure a copy and forward it to you, although I know it will be of very little value.

I have the honor to be,

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 10th inst., file #58-3-1 referring to Miss Delphine Murphy taking charge of the Bel Ground School, about Feb. 3rd. In reply, I beg to inform you that this appears to be a good move, as apparently, all the Indians are desirous that Miss Murphy should again take the school. With regard to reducing, or discontinuing relief on account of children's delinquency, I cannot quite see how this can be done, except on recommendation of the teacher. The way this has been done, and the only way I can see that it can be done in the future, is that the teacher will have to report to me, when any of the children do not attend. However, we will have to improvise a method, whereby the teacher would appear to the Indians, to be responsible for any reduction in relief, that may take place.

I have from time to time, informed the Indians that it was not the teacher's fault, that relief should, or had to be reduced on account of the children staying home.

I never was of the opinion that the teacher of an Indian school should act as truant officer, as it always is the cause of hard feelings between the two. However, I do not think there will be any difficulty in getting things to run satisfactorily at this school.

Mr. A. Lee Fraser, Indian Agent, Rexton, N.B.

Miss Delphine Murphy, teacher of the Bel Ground School, has recently written a letter to the Minister requesting financial assistance in the matter of transportation to and from the school to her home. A somewhat similar request was received recently from another source and at that time we decided to increase Miss Murphy's salary by $50 a year. In this regard I would refer you to my letter of June 10.

As you are probably aware, Miss Murphy had an accident some years ago and, although we did not wish to re-appoint her to the Bel Ground School, she insisted on obtaining that school and we reluctantly acceded to her request. It is very unusual for teachers of Indian day schools to write to the Minister, as the Departmental officials are at all times willing to reasonably consider requests from teachers. The Department wishes you to see Miss Murphy at the earliest possible date and point out to her that if she is not satisfied with conditions now existing at Bel Ground it would be advisable for her to apply for a transfer to some other school.

In her letter to the Minister Miss Murphy states that it will cost her $2.50 a day for transportation during the academic year 1944-45. If this figure is correct, the Department cannot understand how Miss Murphy can afford to pay the amount. Certainly it is not our intention to increase her salary more than the amount about which you have already been advised.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I have been teaching at the Indian Reserve, Bel Ground, N.B., for the past six years, with most gratifying results. I wish to continue my work there but owing to war conditions transportation to and fro has become a problem. Next term I expect to pay $2.50 a day for unsatisfactory service at best, and I know you will agree with me that our salaries are not sufficient for such expense.

After due consideration, I think that my problem would be solved if the Department would help me purchase a car that I could use for transportation, or help pay towards my transportation.

I would be most grateful, dear Mr. Maloney, if you would write the Government in my behalf and acquaint them with this matter.

I wish to thank you in advance, and trust to receive a favorable reply at an early date.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Crerar:

I enclose herewith letter received from Miss Delphine Murphy of Newcastle, N.B., which is self-explanatory.

I have known Miss Murphy from childhood, and I know her statement with regard to transportation to be true. It is impossible to procure board and lodgings at or near Bel Ground and as a result, she has to reside at home. The distance from her home to Bel Ground and return, is about 11 miles. I believe she has 42 pupils which is about equal to the number at Burnt Church, where they have two teachers. However, she is not complaining about the number of pupils and wishes to continue with the school, but she feels the Department should meet part of the cost of transportation.

I feel her request is very reasonable and I would appreciate your very kind consideration in her behalf.

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Maloney:

I have for acknowledgment your confidential letter of June 12 and also letter dated June 6, 1944, received by you from Miss Delphine Murphy, teacher at the Bel Ground Indian Day School.

I may state that this is the third letter I have received in the last few days, all of which asked that special consideration be given to the request for an increased salary or allowance sent forward to the Department by this teacher.

I may state briefly that Miss Delphine Murphy was teacher at the Bel Ground Indian Day School during the school year 1939-40. On May 14, 1940, Miss Murphy, while on her way home from school, was assaulted by a certain unknown person, or persons, with the result that she was seriously injured and required hospital and medical care for a number of months. Immediately following her recovery Miss Murphy petitioned the Department for a transfer and was given the position of teacher at the Cromocto Indian Day School. For some reason or another known only to herself, Miss Murphy became dissatisfied with conditions on the Cromocto Reserve and requested to be retransferred to Bel Ground. In this connection I am sending forward, for your information, copies of correspondence that took place between Miss Murphy and the Department at that time. The subject matter of this correspondence, you will note, is self-explanatory.

J.W. Maloney, Esq.,
Newcastle, N.B.
Miss Murphy was given an increase in salary in 1942 and will receive an additional increase this year. In other words, Miss Murphy will receive, during the academic year 1944-45, the highest salary paid to an Indian day school teacher in the Province of New Brunswick. This salary will amount to $35 a month, regular salary, plus $14.45, cost-of-living bonus, or a total of $99.45.

We have never at any time purchased automobiles for the use of Indian day school teachers and I regret that it is not possible to even seriously consider this suggestion in view of the critical period in which we now find ourselves. It is just possible, in view of all the circumstances, that Miss Murphy might well be advised by her friends to seek a new position, preferably in a well-established white settlement in the province.

May I, however, thank you for your interest in this matter and for the courtesy that prompted you to bring it to my personal attention.

Yours sincerely,

RAH

Memorandum:

- Director -

The following is a brief report of my two day - October 12-13 - visit to the New Brunswick East Agency.

SCHOOL - is a good building in excellent condition - very clean. Children health and well-dressed. The attendance during September and October was interrupted as a number of children accompanied their parents to Maine to pick potatoes. On their return to the reserve a number of the older boys stayed away from school to cut Christmas trees. These children being absent from school for such a long period interferes with the teacher's work as practically all the lessons must be reviewed and gone over on their return making it impossible for the teacher to obtain the results that she should. Instructions were issued to the Chief to advise the parents of the boys cutting Christmas Trees that they must return to school immediately. There may have been some excuse to permit school children to go to Maine to harvest the potato crop as a war effort. Now, however, the family Allowances, I would strongly recommend that agents in the maritime Provinces, as well as Eastern Quebec, be informed that this practice henceforth must be discontinued. As the branch is providing good schools with capable instructors then we must insist that the children attend regularly during the full school term.

Chief Dan Paul stated that it was impossible to obtain the services of an Indian man as janitor for the school for the small sum of $50.00 a year. During the past two or three years Miss Murphy, the teacher, was going to school early in the morning to get fires started, and she was allowed the amount of $50.00 in addition to her regular salary for doing this work. Miss Murphy is most anxious to be relieved of this task, and as a man could not be obtained for the amount allotted arrangements were made that a fourteen year old school boy - Reginal Winish - living adjacent to the school - would look after the fires for the amount

(over)
provided. Reginald is a strong, sturdy, boy, and is quite capable of doing the work. Miss Murphy appears to be quite competent, very interested in her work, and has full control of the children at all times.

J.E. Morris,
Welfare Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

In reply to your letter of June 13th. File-55-3-1, I would say that I visited Miss Delphine Murphy, teacher of the Bel Ground Dya School, at her home in Newcastle, on June 18th, and pointed out to her that it was very unethical for an ordinary employee of the Department to approach the Minister with matters which in their logical course should be handled through the Indian agents office. I feel that Miss Murphy should already have known the proper course to pursue in matters pertaining to schools.

It is however my belief that in this particular case Miss Murphy had been badly advised, first by a former employee of the Department, whose policy has always been to go directly to the Minister and secondly by the party who enclosed Miss Murphy's letter with one of his own to the Minister.

Miss Murphy when I spoke to her was quite willing to carry on next year with the increase of $50 mentioned in your letter of June 10th, and of which I informed her on June 12th by letter.

I feel that in the future Miss Murphy will direct any requests she may have to make, through the proper channels.

OTTAWA, November 3rd, 1921.

Madam,

Replying to your letter regarding your salary for the quarter ended September 30th, I beg to say that a cheque, #1849, for $112.50, being the amount of salary due for that quarter, as well as cheque, #2397, for $15.00, being the amount of bonus due, was sent you addressed to South Esk, N.B., on the 17th of October, last. This was the address to which cheques for former teachers were sent, and it is regretted that in sending these cheques they were not addressed to you at Strathadam. If you communicate with the postmaster at South Esk he will, no doubt, forward you the letter containing these cheques.

Regarding the amount which was sent you for bonus - $15 - I beg to say that the bonus allowed teachers for the present fiscal year ending March 31st, next, is paid on a monthly basis of $15.00 per month for ten teaching months. For the June quarter last you received payment for three months, and for the September quarter, as school was only open during the month of September, you are only entitled to bonus for one month.

Kindly inform the Department whether you receive these cheques or not.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Rebecca Isaacs,
Teacher, Eel Ground Indian Day School,
Box 3, Strathadam, N.B.
Strathcona Box 3
No. 11 Oct. 1921.

Will oblige,

Yours truly,
Rebecca Isaacs

Sir:

In reference to your letter of the 16th ultimo File 55-3-5 touching on repairs for the Bel Ground Indian Day school, I beg to say that the necessary work has been done, but I never yet asked for authority to purchase the 8 new desks recommended by Rev. Father Ryan. Those seats can be purchased near Newcastle at Chatham, and can be placed in a day or two. If you give me the authority I will have them placed immediately.

Your obedient servant

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 26th, 1930.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 20th instant, relative to the eight extra desks required for the use of the Eel Ground Indian Day School. In this connection, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery at the school of eight desks of the type and size required. It is noted that you can obtain these desks at Chatham. After you have made the purchase, you should forward accounts in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost. Please arrange to have the desks supplied and set up in the classroom as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes.
For Secretary.

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N. B.

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of the Eel Ground Indian Day School, recommends that during the coming summer holidays the ceiling of the classroom be kalsomined, the woodwork washed, the floor scrubbed, and, when thoroughly dry, given a coat of oil, also that some glass requires to be replaced. He also recommends that the out houses be thoroughly cleaned, whitewashed inside and placed in a good, sanitary condition.

I have to request that you will bear this matter in mind and have the above work carried out during the coming summer holidays. All costs for the purpose should be kept as low as possible and, when the work is completed, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Rev. F. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools, reports as follows regarding the Eel Ground Indian Day School which he visited on the 15th instant:

"The interior of the school should be kalsomined, the floor and wainscot well washed and floor oiled when dry, with hot oil.

The teacher uses her house during the winter months as her boarding house is a long distance from the reserve. Now the interior of this house must be put in order; kalsomined, a bed should be purchased, and 2 or 3 blankets given, a cupboard and 2 or 3 chairs, dishes, also purchased. Minor repairs are required. The pump in the kitchen is out of order and must be repaired.

The out houses must be cleaned, whitewashed and repaired. Step at school cared for."

Please forward to the Department a detailed estimate of the expenditure that would be required to carry out the Inspector's suggestions. On receipt of your report, the Department will be in a position to decide if the necessary funds can be provided.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR RYAN on his inspection of the Eel Ground Indian Day School.

Date of Inspection - October 19, 1937.

"We have here a very small old school building with a "L" built on same for a teacher's residence, also a shed and two outhouses, all belonging to the Government. The school house has long been condemned. By leaving this old school just as it is attached to the teacher's residence, it could serve for a domestic science hall and teacher's home. We require such a hall. A new school could be constructed just above the old one - in any case, we must have a new school at once or by next year."
Ottawa, November 8, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Reporting on his inspection of the Eel Ground Indian Day School on October 19th Inspector Ryan writes:

"We have here a very small old school building with a "L" built on same for a teacher's residence, also a shed and two outhouses, all belonging to the Government. The school house has long been condemned. By leaving this old school just as it is attached to the teacher's residence, it could serve for a domestic science hall and teacher's home. We require such a hall. A new school could be constructed just above the old one - in any case, we must have a new school at once or by next year."

I would appreciate receiving from you a full report regarding the present condition of the Eel Ground School.

I might add that our funds will not permit favorable consideration being given to the erection of a new school this year.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply I would say that the school building is really too small but is fairly comfortable. It could be used for the purpose the Inspector recommends, although I am not sure the teacher will use the residence as it has not been used for a long time.

In regard to a new building I would say that it was necessary, but it is entirely too late in the season to commence such work as the winter is nearly here. Probably an Officer of the Department might visit this agency next summer, when he could decide whether it would be better to build a new school house, or enlarge the old one.

I might state that the roof of the above named building will have to be shingled next year.

Ottawa, June 24, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of May 12th, regarding repairs required at the Eel Ground Indian Day School.

I regret that I was unable to visit New Brunswick during the month of June, as formerly planned, but hope to have the opportunity of going there during the month of September.

I note, from the first paragraph of your letter, that the Eel Ground School is too small for the attendance. As no funds were provided in this year's appropriation for a new building, it is not possible to consider such action at the present time. However, if it is later found that a new building is required, the provision of funds for its erection can be further considered when preparing our estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40.

From the last paragraph of your letter, I note that you consider the present school should be reshingled and some other repairs and alterations made. Our funds are extremely limited, but you might let me have an estimate of the cost of the work that you consider absolutely necessary. If the material required will cost over $50.00, you should let me have detailed information in this connection, in order that the order may be placed through our Purchasing Branch.

Funds at our disposal will not permit giving favourable consideration to painting the building this year.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of building data form with reference to the proposed erection of a new school on the Eel Ground Reserve.

Provision will be made for a class room to accommodate 40 pupils but no rolling partition will be placed in the building as the Department considers this unnecessary.

Do you consider it advisable to attach teacher's living quarters to the school or can the teacher secure accommodation close to the school? We do not wish to provide living accommodation at the school if it is not necessary.

We do not favour supplying a cess pool at an Indian day school. Our experience shows that they are continually going out of order and extra expense is entailed. Would it not be possible to locate the school in such a manner that there would be natural drainage?

It is not our intention to supply flush toilets in the basement. These are not only expensive to install but there would be a steady maintenance cost.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th instant File 55-3-5 referring to erection of a new school on the Eel Ground Reserve, and in reply beg to inform you with regard to teachers' quarters, that I do not consider it necessary to have such an addition to the school, as there is a very fair teachers' residence attached to the old school; I also will add that these quarters have not been used by the teachers for about eight years, as they board with white people near the reserve; but they are in good repair and fit for occupation if needed.

With regard to toilets, flush bowls were suggested by the Inspector of Indian schools, but my own opinion is that outdoor toilets for this school would be quite suitable, and if these were supplied instead of flush toilets, there would be no need of a cesspool or a long drain.

If a furnace is installed, and this will necessarily have to be in the basement, we might have to construct an ordinary drain of about 100 feet in length, to keep the basement dry, but I am not sure of this. How would it be to leave the drain until after the school is erected and we find whether it is needed or not. It would not be an expensive job and would not cost any more a little later than it would now. It would take quite a little survey work to determine whether water would lodge in the basement or not, but as the building will be erected on an incline to the river, I do not believe it will.

With regard to the rolling partition, it was a recommendation of the Inspector of Indian schools and with every respect for his suggestion, but I do not think it is necessary.

Dear Sir:

With regard to the old school building on the Bel Ground Reserve, when the new one was built you advised me that the old building could be given to Mike Bernard of the Bel Ground Reserve, if he would remove it without cost to the Department, but Bernard could not do this and so later I had orders to give it to any Indians who would tear it down and remove it from the location on which it stood, and use the material for repairing their houses. This building has stood there (an eyesore to the place) until about a week ago when I had Dan Paul, Peter Barnaby, and another Indian John Battust of the Bel Ground Reserve to undertake the job of taking down and removing the debris. These men have the building partly dismantled and now a number of other Indians have joined together and won't let this work proceed. I would like to have definite orders from you as to what course to take in order that this job can be completed.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 26th instant in which you intimate that a number of Indians have joined together to prevent the dismantling of the old abandoned school on the Eel Ground Reserve.

It is difficult for the officials here to understand or interpret correctly this attitude on the part of the Indians. It would appear from this distance to be an expression of lawlessness. The matter is one that should be taken up immediately with the police. If these Indians are attempting to arrest, in any way, the work at the school, or if they are interfering in any way with the work of dismantling the building, the police should be notified and these Indians arrested and brought before a court of competent jurisdiction.

Dear Sir:

We are in this Province studying a plan under which the single room Rural Schools may be improved. Last week I visited schools in Northumberland County and was fortunate enough to see the Indian School at Eel Ground, near Newcastle. The plans and appointments of this school impressed me very favorably and I have been directed by the Minister of Education here to inquire of your Department as to whether or not the plans and specifications of this school can be obtained and, if so, on what terms. The school possesses many features which we would like to see in all rural schools. Any assistance you would like to give us in this connection would be appreciated.

Yours sincerely,

[Fletcher Peacock]

Mr. F.J. Hudson, In Charge Indian Agency, Richibucto, N.B.

Four large panes of glass for classroom windows.
One kitchen sink for teachers residence to cost not more than $12.00

**Red Bank.**

One new door for school entrance, to cost not more than $19.00, including casing.
Repair to school steps requiring not more than 100 feet lumber.
A number of seats to be repaired requiring not more than one days labor.
Six panes of glass.

Repairs to school steps and steps of wood shed requiring not more than 200 feet of lumber.

In reference to Voucher No. 657 I would say that shortly before the Bel Ground Indian Day school opened in September last year Miss Delphine Murphy, the teacher, informed me that the furnace in the school needed some repair before it could be used. I instructed her to have Mr. Maltby make the repairs but I was under the impression that there was only one grate needed. However when he took the furnace down he found the whole firebox had to be built over and he renewed the whole firebox.

The bill was forwarded to this office late in December and I was rather surprised at the amount of same. When Dr. McGill visited the Agency he told me that I would probably be called into Ottawa some time in January. I therefore decided that I would hold the bill and would give a verbal account to the proper branch if called to Ottawa. Since I have not been called in I am forwarding the bill with the recommendation that it be paid, as the work was absolutely necessary.

Indian Agent.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of 16th inst. is received.

I can supply the brown flannel you mention with the grey also white flannel, but it is impossible to supply the Brent and dark flannel as they are not to be had in Newcastle.

If your Dept. could authorize any supplier to send me a few pieces of Brent and dark flannel I would be pleased to distribute it, also if they wished to get other items instead of the Brent etc. would it be satisfactory to supply it up to say $8 or $10 dollars worth. As we have no stock at the present time Shirley flannel @ 4½¢ also White flannel @ 3½¢ per yd., but as you know quantity and variety is very limited.

Northeastern Division,
Buctouche, April 29, 1914.

Sir;-

I have the honour to report, that the Teacher
of the Bel Ground Indian school, has applied to have
a residence suitable for her, to be built in
connection with this school. There is no boarding
house any way near occupied by white people and she
is compelled to travel considerable distance night
and morning in order to get board. I may say that a
small addition could be built to the present school
building, which could be made quite comfortable for
about from $400.00 to $500.00.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

A FEW OF THE ADVANTAGES OF BRICK CONSTRUCTION.

For appearance; durability and fire resistance, brick buildings are unsurpassed.

(A.) Appearance: dignified, always attractive and lasting. For the reason that brick buildings associate with any surroundings, brick construction is the most attractive in any situation. Ornate concrete, stone or terra cotta buildings are out of place in the average town of the Maritime Provinces. They are too "new."

(B.) Durability: practically speaking, brick lasts forever. The life of a well made brick building is endless. Brick buildings do not require the upkeep and repairs of other buildings.

(C.) Economy in construction, maintenance and insurance rates. Costs little, if any, more to build with brick than with wood. Brick is cheaper than stone for construction.

(D.) Fire resistance. Brick is the greatest known fire resisting material. Concrete and stone buildings are fireproof and non-crumbling, but only the brick chimney standing. Bricks are put through a process of heat and manufacture which does not apply to the same degree. Concrete and stone, although non-combustible in themselves, will crumble when subjected to heat and water.

Dear Sir,

I am writing to tell you of a few things necessary in dwelling attached to Elginwood school.

In the first place, the pump, which was installed last Christmas, has been out of order ever since. You see, the cellar is an icehouse in the winter, and the pump froze, but fortunately the pipes didn't burst. And after it thawed out, when we went to pump, the water instead of coming out the spout, went all over the floor. What it needs is a new rubber, and the nuts tightened. Everyone who sees it says pump is no good anyway. I don't think myself it is, as nuts will not stay tight. A point is needed, but Mr. Hudson told me he was going to try for a stint. Also the floors here are in a bad condition. They are badly worn in some places, and paint wears right off. Hardwood flooring is needed for down stairs, and it would take very little, the house is costing.

Then we haven't a blind on any of the four windows. I think Mr. Hudson ordered them.
but through some mistake they didn't come.

Another thing Elginwood is badly in need of, no a telephone. It would take about five days to bring wire from main highway to here. When we want a telephone we've got to go a distance of 2 miles. We badly needed a Dr. badly on two occasions during night, but having no telephone, I had to wait until morning.

Now Mr. Terrell knows you'll be thinking I'm acting too much, but if you'll consider cost, you'll find it won't amount to very much, and what comfort those things would give to any teacher staying here.

I remain,

Yours sincerely,

Katherine O'Hea

P.S. Mr. Terrell received word from you stating you were having Red Cross Junior papers sent to this school, but up to date have received no copies.

Sir:

A communication has been received from the teacher of the Eel Ground Indian Day School in which she draws attention to the present condition of the pump. She states that it has been out of order since it was installed last Christmas, and that she was informed that it is unserviceable. She also requests that a sink be installed in the kitchen and that hardwood floors be laid in the downstairs portion of the residence.

I have to request that you will give immediate attention to having the pump placed in a serviceable condition. If the present pump is unsatisfactory, you may purchase and have installed a new pump of a type satisfactory to meet the requirements. No unnecessary expense should be incurred, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost.

Please report as to whether you would advise that a sink be installed, also the hardwood flooring asked for by the teacher. If you recommend that this work be carried out, please furnish an estimate of the cost of installing the sink and hardwood flooring.

I shall be pleased if you will arrange to purchase the 2 screen doors and 4 screens for the windows which you were authorized in our letter of the 26th instant to supply.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N.B.
In reply to your letter of May 28th concerning a communication from the teacher of the Eel Ground Indian Day School saying that the pump was not in a serviceable condition, I would say that I intended to examine this pump when I next visited Eel Ground, and find what repairs it needed: The pump worked perfect when it was installed, I am sure of this as I examined it at the time; the teacher also told me that it was fine. The trouble is, that it was necessary, in very cold weather, to let the priming out of it at night, this she neglected to do, the consequence was that it froze and split the piping. I will have it repaired at once.

I think it would be advisable for me to go up to the reserve in connection with the installing of the sink and placing hardwood floor in the residence, as I don't think it is necessary to do either. I would have to examine the place before making any recommendation, especially for the sink, as it would mean also a cess-pool and this would make it necessary to expend two or three hundred dollars; I think that she could get along without the sink and hardwood floor, but I would not be sure until I would make an examination.

I have already arranged for the screen doors and windows for this residence at Eel Ground.

OTTAWA, 20th November, 1903

Sir,

Mr. Barrie, barrister-at-law, of Dalhousie calls attention to the need of a school for the Indians of the Bel River reserve and states that there are about thirty children running wild there.

Your last published report shows that the total population of the band is 48 and that some of these have removed from the reserve. With the small number of children of school age shown in your Census return, the Department does not see how it would be possible to keep up a sufficient attendance to justify the establishment of a school and the payment of a teacher's salary. As however, it does not wish these children to grow up in ignorance, it would be willing to pay a tuition grant for any of them who would attend white schools in the neighborhood, and it would like you to make enquiries in this direction.

Ottawa, August 2, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo in reference to the establishment of a school for the Bel River Indians.

In reply I beg to say that the Department desires fuller information before it can come to any decision in this matter. You should state the number of families with the number of children of school age in each family who could attend the school and the distance that they would have to go; also whether there are white schools which they might attend and, if so, what distance they would have to travel in this case. You should also state whether these Indians are all permanently located. If the conditions are such as to warrant the expenditure the Department will be prepared to consider the matter of establishing a school. I may say, however, that the sum of money mentioned in your letter would hardly put up a modern building. If decided that it would be well to open a school on this reserve might it not be possible to rent a building for a short time until it can be seen what interest the Indians will take in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Indian Superintendent,

I have the honour to report in reference to your communication of the above number of the Second of August ultimo, that there are fifteen families residing on the "Eel River Reserve" Restigouche County, N.B., twelve of which are now permanently located and have children of school age, and the number of children that could attend school would be about nineteen or twenty. Sir,

Ottawa, December 17th, 1913

I take great pleasure in presenting my report for my inspection of the different reserves in the province of New Brunswick.

At the Epa-Fe River Reserve the school was only opened up on the beginning of January and it is surprising the progress made by the teacher Miss La Blanc. She had an attendance of 19 without an absentee in the last month. The children are very fond of going to school and every encouragement should be offered to the teacher. The building is too small and better accommodation should be provided next year. An outside door is needed at the west of the building, as daylight could be seen through the cracks and the teacher said that it made the building very cold during the winter months.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir:

Wm. Narvie, of the Bel River Reserve, visited the Department today and among other matters complained of the irregular attendance of the teacher, Miss Antoinette Blanchard. He stated that she does not keep the school open during the regular hours, and is frequently absent and the school closed. He also stated that she is inefficient and claimed that the children are making no progress in their studies. He had letters from a number of Indian complaining of the services the teacher is performing, and requested, on behalf of the band, that a change be made for the next school year. We are referring this matter to you and will be pleased to have your views as to whether you would advise that the services of Miss Blanchard be discontinued at the end of the present school year and the services of another teacher engaged.

It might be well to inform Miss Blanchard that it is expected she will open and close the school at the regular hours, and that she is not to close the school, except for unavoidable reasons, during the period it should regularly be kept open.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing a communication which you received from Miss Alice Tremblay, teacher of the Eel River Indian Day School, in which she states that on account of illness it will be necessary for her to give up teaching for several months. The application which you forwarded from Miss Genevieve Fitzgerald to teach this school during the illness of Miss Tremblay was also received, together with a copy of a testimonial regarding her previous services, as well as a communication from Rev. Father Hackett with reference to his illness of Miss Tremblay. The Department regrets Miss Tremblay's illness and hopes that after a few months' rest from teaching duties her health will have recovered.

Regarding the appointment of Miss Fitzgerald, I have to confirm the following telegram sent you today:

"Temporary appointment Miss G. Fitzgerald approved as teacher Eel River Indian Day School during illness Miss Tremblay. Writing".

The qualifications which Miss Fitzgerald possesses have been noted, and it is considered that her services would be satisfactory for the balance of the present school year, if necessary for her to continue as teacher for that length of time. The salary allowed Miss Fitzgerald will be at the same rate as was paid Miss Tremblay, viz., $70 per teaching month. I shall be pleased if you will arrange with Miss Fitzgerald to take up duties at the earliest possible date.

We are informing Mr. Agent Hudson of the arrangements made for the continuing of the teaching services at the Eel River School by Miss Fitzgerald owing to the illness of Miss Tremblay.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
