MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Reverend P. C. Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for New Brunswick, in a report on his recent inspection of the Indian Day School on the Bel River Reserve, No. 3, (Federal Electoral District of Restigouche-Shadawakas), N. B., reports regarding the present teacher, Miss Alice Tremblay, as follows:-

"The pupils did only fair work. This school is and has been on the decline for the past two or three years. I would suggest a new teacher. We have carried her along, knowing her health has not been the best. Her illness, as well as her disposition, is against her in meeting with success in an Indian school." Father Ryan recommends dispensing with her services and the appointment of Miss Blanche Leona Arsenault, Shediac, N. B., who holds a first class superior license, coming third in rank in the province of New Brunswick in 1933.

This school, while located in the province of New Brunswick, has been placed, for administrative purposes, under the supervision of the Agent of the Restigouche Agency, province of Quebec. The Department considered dispensing with Miss Tremblay's services but agreed to allow her to teach until the end of June. I would suggest that Father Ryan's recommendation be approved, that Miss Tremblay's services be dispensed with and that Miss Blanche L. Arsenault be appointed to succeed her for the coming school year, with salary at the same rate.

I may add that, in the past, the Department has left the nomination of teachers for the Indian schools in New Brunswick in the hands of Reverend Father Ryan.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Reverend Sir:

Sir,

I trust you to hear my story which I am confident will convince you that I have been unjustly treated. For years I have been engaged as teacher of the Indian School in Kelowna. I have on file a letter from the Indian Agent, dated June 15th, stating that the Dept. informed me that I was to remain in charge of the school for the year 1936-37. Believing myself re-engaged I did not apply for other schools.
accepting for three I had applied for in May and I refused accepting the Summeride School in Darlington so I felt I was now bound to keep the Indian School and also because I was content with my former position.

July 15th. Received a letter from Mr. T. C. Ryan, the Inspector of Indian Schools stating that he had engaged a first class teacher in my stead. He also stated that when he inspected the school that he had told me this was to be done. This is not so, I am sorry to say. He did say that the Dept. intended reducing the number of reserves in N.B. to four and in that case it would be better for the teachers to look for other schools, but I asked him if no such change were made if I would be re-engaged, he said "yes so far as I know."
I do not know what report was made against me but I have discharged my duties just as faithfully as usual and do not feel guilty about my conduct.

As you see that I have lost all chances of obtaining another position as it is now too late so I was discharged July the 24th only, could you be so kind as to use your influence to obtain for me a position with the Indian Dept such as clerking in the Book Dept, or a librarian or any such work even though the salary would not be very high.

Thanking you so much.

I am,

Yours most obliged,

[Signature]

Dear Sir:

I have a suggestion to make which I would like the department to consider.

The Eel River Bar Indian Day School is scheduled to open Oct. 1, 1941. The changing of this date to Sept. 1, with the month of January taken off, leaving the school opened for a new months' period as ordered, is, I consider, a profitable change for the following reasons:

(1) During the first month of school, the attendance at school is always larger than during the cold month of January. The fact that the children are poorly clothed accounts for this.

(2) Closing schools for the duration of the month of January would mean a considerable saving in fuel.

(3) From my experience as a teacher, I am not in favour of too long holidays. Three months' holidays without interruption, is too long for the average rural school.

I hope that my application will be considered favourably, but should the department decide otherwise, I shall abide by its decision.

Yours very truly,

Dear Madam,-

This will acknowledge your letter of July 4 addressed to the Comptroller of the Treasury, Ottawa, Canada.

Under the provisions of the Dominion Income Tax Act, 1942, employers were required to make deductions from the salaries of all employees for National Defence Tax and Income Tax purposes. The Act also required the employer to furnish the Inspector of Income Tax with a statement of the earnings of each employee and showing deductions made for National Defence or Income Tax for the period employed in the year 1942. This statement of earnings was forwarded to the Inspector of Income Tax on your account and the copy which you note in your letter was forwarded for your information.

The Income Tax Act further required each person to complete and forward a copy of an income tax return to the Inspector of Income Tax by June 30, 1943.

I am enclosing you copies of the income tax form, and would suggest that you complete these forms forwarding one copy to the Inspector of Income Tax and retaining one for your own information. On the form you should show your total income, income tax, if any, and the deductions which were made by your employer at the source of payment; and if you have been over-taxed, request a refund from the Inspector of Income Tax in the space provided on the form.

Yours truly,

L.W. McCutcheon

Ottawa, November 19, 1926.

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan has recommended that an increase in salary be allowed Miss Alice Tremblay, teacher of the Bel River Indian Day School. He states that she is teaching domestic science to the children and the women of the reserve and that her services in the classroom are satisfactory.

The Department will allow Miss Tremblay an increase of $5 per teaching month from the first of October, last. This increase is made in lieu of any remuneration for her services in the teaching of domestic science. Therefore, from the date mentioned, Miss Tremblay's salary will be paid at the rate of $70 per teaching month. I have to request that you will inform her of the increase in salary allowed and point out that same is to remunerate her for her services in the teaching of domestic science.

Sir:

Father Ryan, together with a letter from Miss Alice Tremblay, teacher of the Bel River Indian Day School, in which she states that owing to ill health it will be necessary for her to give up duties for a period of at least two months, and, if her health does not sufficiently improve in that time, she will be absent from duty for the balance of the present school year. Father Ryan also forwarded an application from Miss Genevieve Fitzgerald, Newcastle, N.B., for temporary appointment during the illness of Miss Tremblay. Sanitary School Furniture

Extracts from Enrolled Educators and Physicians Views as to What Constitutes Perfect Hygienic Equipment.

The conservation of health and prevention of contagious diseases and physical defects demand certain specific requirements in relation to the proper seating of pupils in our public schools. Every pupil should have a seat of such height that the feet rest easily on the floor. The desk should be high enough not to touch the knees, and yet allow sufficient space for school books within the desk top low enough for the arm to rest comfortably without much raising of the elbow. The neck should support the proper slope and sustain the correct angle with its back, which back should support the spinal column at the small of the back, also at a point just below the shoulder blades. The seat should be near enough so that the scholar may reach the desk for writing without leaning too far forward, and thus losing the support of his back. The seat should not be so close as to cause pressure against the side of the hip or rear end to interfere with easy sitting. It must be wide enough not to extend fourteen inches from the front edge of desk to seat back, and the seat must not project under the desk more than four inches.

Our Stationery Desks are built in six sizes, one inch apart to meet the above conditions on the mouth of schools. Where more accurate adjustment is desirable, we would recommend Adjustable Chair Desk, which can be adjusted to the fraction of an inch in all directions, normal or otherwise.

The materials employed in desk construction, as mentioned elsewhere, are also important. The feet of desks should be so constructed as not to harbor germs or bacteria, and sufficient space allowed for thorough and efficient cleaning by either hand brush or vacuum methods. You will find all these demands are fully met by our GLOBE STEEL SANITARY DESKS.

Ottawa, July 8, 1931.

Sir:

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his inspection, in June last, of the Eel River Indian Day School, states that the ceiling of the classroom is badly cracked and in danger of falling. He recommends that it be sheeted with the same material as the walls. He states, further, that the school steps require some repairs and that the floor of the classroom should be thoroughly scrubbed and oiled and the windows repaired. He reports also that the closets should be thoroughly cleaned and placed in a good, sanitary condition.

I have to request that you will furnish the Department with an estimate of the cost of sheeting the ceiling of the school, including the material and labour. The other work mentioned by Father Ryan should be carried out during the coming summer holidays. Please keep all costs as low as possible and forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

This will be for a first class job not done by Indian labour. I would recommend that it is a necessary expenditure.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, August 1, 1931.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of the repairs required to the ceiling of the classroom and the steps at the entrance to the Eel River Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging to have the ceiling of this building sheeted with the same material as the walls. When this work is done, the ceiling should be stained and varnished. You should also arrange to build or repair the steps to the door and have same painted. Please purchase the material and make arrangements for the labour. In this connection you should be guided by instructions which you have received regarding purchases. You should see that a satisfactory job is completed before the school re-opens; and, after the work has been finished to your satisfaction, please forward a certified account, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. Besides the above work, you should also have the floor of the classroom thoroughly scrubbed and oiled and the windows repaired, as instructed by official letter of the 8th ultimo.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, June 28th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

In reporting regarding his inspection of the Kel River Indian Day School on the 14th instant, Inspector Ryan writes:

"The interior of the school, being totally finished in Douglas fir, should be well washed, ceiling, walls, etc. After the floor dries well for a few days, a good coat of hot oil should be applied. The outhouses should be repaired and whitewashed. Some minor repairs should be made about fence. Grounds are in fair condition. PP/MGD
Re: Repairs of Eel River Indian School.

The present is to inform the Department that the Eel River Indian Day School should have repairs next summer,...or build a new one in order to give place for the children.

The present school (seems to me) a very old building, not comfortable and too small for the number of children.

The school is very cold on account of the air drafts coming from the floor, the windows, and even the corners; according to the sayings of the teacher, as soon as the furnace fire is out the class becomes cold in a short time and it takes a long time in the morning before having comfortable heat in the class.

I have noticed at my last visit that the teacher and the pupils had their overcoats on in the afternoon, and they told me it was on account they were freezing....I was cold myself after my visit........

Probably some repairs would improve the situation for a certain time, but it would cost an appreciable amount of money and still we would have an old building too small for the pupils.

At present four pupils are obliged to seat down behind the desks with ordinary chairs (with no back) because the lack of space in the class. Although no provision has been made in the year's estimates for that new school, I would ask the Dept. to consider the possibility of the erection of a new school for Eel River reserve.

Memorandum:

Colonel B. F. Neary,
Superintendent of Training.

Re: Bel River Day School, N.B.

On June 8th, 1948, I visited the Bel Indian Reserve at the request of Major Patrick, who wanted me to inspect the Veterans' houses and also with the permission of Mr. J. E. Morris, Acting Inspector Indian Agencies.

I was accompanied by Superintendent E. Arsenault, Restigouche Indian Agency, and it was found that the Bel River Indian Day School needs some repairs:

(1). The entrance bridge is in very bad shape and I suggested that a 24" galvanized iron pipe, or a cement pipe, be put in the ditch and covered with gravel.
(2). The entrance steps of the School should also be repaired, or new ones built.
(3). Build a teacher's platform in the classroom and take out a small altar which has been built inside this classroom. The altar does not seem to be in use at the present time.
(4). Furnish them with a drinking fountain.
(5). Paint the inside of the School.
(6). Change the stove for a bigger one, as this stove is too small to heat the classroom properly.
(7). Fix the foundation of this School, as it is all breaking up and freezing the inside of the School.
(8). Outside toilets are in very bad shape, dirty and should be re-built.

These repairs were requested by Mr. Arsenault and the Indians of this Reserve. I told them that I would refer this matter to your Branch. You could, therefore, if you wish write to Mr. Arsenault and find out the approximate cost of these repairs.

J.E. Gendron,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies

Mr. E. Arsenault, Superintendent,
Indian Agency, Restigouche, P.Q.

With reference to the Eel River Indian Day School, Regional Supervisor Gendron recommends that the following repairs be made:

(1) The entrance bridge is in very bad shape and I suggested that a 24" galvanized iron pipe, or a cement pipe, be put in the ditch and covered with gravel.

(2) The entrance steps of the school should also be repaired, or new ones built.

(3) Build a teacher's platform in the classroom and take out a small altar which has been built inside this classroom. The altar does not seem to be in use at the present time.

(4) Furnish them with a drinking fountain.

(5) Paint the inside of the school.

(6) Change the stove for a bigger one, as this stove is too small to heat the classroom properly.

(7) Fix the foundation of this school, as it is all breaking up and freezing the inside of the school.

(8) Outside toilets are in very bad shape, dirty, and should be re-built.
You may arrange for what is required in connection with items 1, 2, 3 and 4. In connection with the other items; you should let us know the cost of painting the inside of the school. You should also state at what price you could secure a larger stove. We also wish to know the cost of fixing the foundation of the school and what expenditure would be required to rebuild the toilets.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

As school was opening this morning Sept. 7 I went to open it and it was in a terrible condition. The inside was supposed to be painted, the desks fixed, new chairs and desk for teachers, water supply, sink, door steps fixed, floor washed absolutely nothing done also about the new fire system, and it is quite hard for me to keep these pupils and myself healthy in such a dirty school. The stone is in no condi...
for this winter and also
the school will be close half
the time. I would really
like an oil heater as it
is very clean for a school.
If you think it will be
hard for you to find a
man to paint I could have

we really need water to
drink and also a place
to wash our hands.
You want them to be
healthy but there is no
way for them to be,
the toilets are not fit for
no one. No arrangements
of any kind for the pupils
at school.
I can't teach in a school
like that.
I wrote Mr. Arsenault
many times but no reply
of any kind. I asked him
for a medicine list and
I didn't get it yet. I filled a few forms this summer. I hope you received them.

About Jane Nannie who completed her Grade IX she did not get no satisfactory answer about going to college, now that the school are all open and quite late for college she would like to go to Dalhousie school which is about three miles from her home and quite hard for her to travel. If she could get a bike I think she would be pleased for this year come really I have eight grades and its more work for me without taking Grade IX. I am very anxious to see my school work so there is one but with more comfort. I am taking all call every morning until
everything is clear up,
I hope you will understand
and that you will see fit
at once.
I made all my complaints
at the end of June but
no attention to it.
Hope I am not annoying
you too much and I would
like a prompt answer,

Oct. 23rd, 1929

Dept. of Ind. Affairs:
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I have the honor to inform you that there are now 30 Indian children living at present, without a school on the Island Reserve, some 9 miles below RICHMONDTON, Kent Co., N.B.

It appears that 5 or 6 of these children have been going to a French school in past years; five or six more going to Big Cove Ind. school, as their parents moved there to give their children an education; four or five others are at Baddeck. Again there were a number that have only attained the school age this past year. There are now over 25 children on this RESERVE; I understand they are all young people and a number of children were born there within the past year. This seems to be a coming RESERVE.

All have large families and are healthy, and I understand good living people. A number of our young Big Cove Indians have married and gone to live there. I would suggest that a house be at once rented and a school provided for them; they are very anxious for a school. I trust the Dept. will at once move in this very important matter. We could, in TWO WEEKS, by the good will of all, have our school going.

The Ind. Agent informs me that there is a good house there now vacant that could be rented until a school is built.

Yours respectfully,

J. C. Ryan,
Inspector of Indian schools for N.B.

P.S. The French school was closed this year; they have no school now. This school was about 1/4 mile from this Reserve.
I beg to report on a situation which is developing on the Indian Island reserve, in fact the time has already arrived when I think something will need to be done in order that the children can get schooling.

There are now twenty six children belonging to this reserve, and of these there are about 15 of school age, the remainder are younger. Some of those children did go to a Provincial school that was situated about 2½ miles from the reserve, but now that school is closed and may not open again, and this leaves the Indian children without any chance to go to school.

There is a building owned by an Indian woman on this reserve, that could by some little repair, be made suitable for a school room and teachers residence: This I think could be rented from this woman if the Department so desired. I would not recommend that it would be satisfactory as a permanent school.

Would you please let me know what the Department thinks best to do about this matter.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, November 6th, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 29th ultimo, recommending that a school be provided for the benefit of the Indian children residing on Indian Island Reserve, and stating that you can rent a building that would be suitable, with some repairs, for the purpose of carrying on classroom work.

It is noted you state that there are some twenty-six children belonging to this Reserve, and that of this number about fifteen are of school age. In this connection I would point out that the last census returns (1926) show that there was a total population of twenty-seven Indians all told on this Reserve, four only of which were children of school age.

I shall be pleased if you will state if these Indians are now residing permanently on the Reserve and, if a school was opened, if it could be regularly conducted, or would it only be at different periods during the year. You should also report further regarding the house which you state could be rented and whether the owner would be prepared to make any repairs in view of this Department paying rental for the use of the building. If not, you should report the cost of fitting up the building, and state whether desks would be required, or if tables and benches could be made locally that would be suitable until it is ascertained whether the school would prove a success. Please also state whether you have any teacher in view and the amount of salary that it would be necessary to pay, also if suitable boarding accommodation could be obtained near the school. When we have this information, consideration will be given to the providing of school facilities.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 6th instant. File 55-6-1 referring to the establishment of a school on the Indian Island reserve, and in reply will say that there are 18 children permanently resident on this reserve: Ten of whom are between the ages of 5 and 16 years. There are then three families with 8 children who belong to the reserve but who move away in the winter. Those Indians should be on the reserve if the children could go to school, as some of them go to white schools now and then, which is not satisfactory.

In regard to the length of time a school could be open I would say that it should be conducted throughout the whole school year. And I would add that it appears to me that a domestic science department would be the most necessary part of the school. A teacher to take charge of this school should be qualified to teach the regular classes and also domestic science. At present I have no one in view who would undertake to conduct such a school, but I think one could be found.

The building I spoke of in my letter of October 29th, can be rented for $25.00 per month, and the owner make all necessary repairs without charge.

As for the seats and desks, if the Department does not have any second hand ones on hand in this Province, I think tables and benches that I could have made, would answer the purpose until we could know if the school would be a success.

In regard to the salary of a teacher for this school I think it would be better for the Department to set a figure that they think suitable. In this case I think the teacher could reside in the same building as used for the school and provide their own board, as there are two comfortable rooms in the building besides the room to be used for teaching. Salary should cover teaching regular, and domestic science classes; also board.

If there is any other information that the Department requires in connection with this subject, I will gladly furnish it.

Your obedient servant

Rev. and Dear Sir:

On Indian Island reserve, which is situated about nine miles from Richibucto, there are about 26 children 15 of whom are of school age. These children have now no opportunity of getting schooling. There was a white school situated about 2 miles from this reserve, and some of the Indian children attended that school, but now it is closed with no prospect of ever being opened again, and the Indians are without any chance of schooling.

I might say that at the present time some of those children are with their parents away from the reserve but would come back immediately if a school was established on the reserve. A few are attending a white school, and this is not satisfactory, as I often have complaints, and have been asked why I could not keep the Indians in their own schools.

In regard to a school for this reserve, I wish to point out that a Domestic Science branch would also be necessary, as the Indians of this reserve are very much in need of instructions along these lines. In regard to this I could refer you to Miss Mary Murdoch, as she is familiar with conditions on the Indian Island reserve.

I would like to have your views of this matter, as I know the Department will be willing to do anything that is fair in establishing a school on this reserve if they know it is necessary.
I would also say in connection with this matter that there is a building on the reserve which can be fitted up, without much expense, that would do temporarily for a school and teachers residence, until we would know if the school would be a success.

I might mention that a teacher whom I think would be capable of conducting such a school can be secured at any time.

Trusting that you can give this matter your attention at the earliest possible moment.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Indian Agent
Red Bank, North Id. Co., N.B.

Sir:

All Indian schools have been visited but as I will be absent for a few days, it may be the 2nd week in July before the Dept. receives my Reports,- I might say that little repairs are required, but a new School must be built on Indian Island Reserve near Richibucto. I asked the Indian Agent to give me a Report on same, one that he could "SWEAR" to, so that I would be in a position to carry on, I feel you can fully rely upon the inclosed REPORT, I am rushing this to the Dept. so that there may be plenty of time to have the said school completed before Sept. next. We have now gone too long without this school. I would kindly advise the Dept. that I fear a move will be made soon in a political way to show up how this reserve has been neglected. Please rush plans &c. It might be better for the Dept. to send a man to look over this reserve. We must get things moving to offset any possible trouble that could very easily come out of this case.

F. C. Ryan.

I would advise the Indian Department to allow Miss Mary Savage - age 22 - a bright, smart girl, who stays with her mother on this very lonesome reserve (as the mother would not stay alone) to give the said Mary at least $100.00 per year as janitor and helper to her mother. She helps her mother in house visiting and in general work. She moreover scrubs this school room twice a week, sews for the Indians and helps her mother in teaching Domestic Science.
Ottawa, November 5th, 1930.

Sir,

Rev. Father Ryan, in a report on his recent inspection of the new Indian Island Indian Day School, states that the work is progressing satisfactorily under the charge of Mrs. Savage and that both the Indians and their children are taking an interest in the school. The Inspector states that a cupboard is required in which to keep all school material, also that another stove is necessary. I have to request that you will give an estimate of the cost of having a suitable cupboard built in the school or having one purchased. You should, also, state whether another stove is required and, if so, the type and price. These matters should receive your early attention.

You may purchase and have delivered three pounds of laundry soap, an inexpensive looking glass and a steel comb, forwarding certified accounts in the usual manner covering the cost.

Father Ryan has also recommended that Miss Mary Savage, daughter of the teacher who is assisting her mother in the work and performing janitor's services and who also sews for the Indians and helps her mother in teaching domestic science and in visiting the Indian homes, be granted a small remuneration for these services. The Department will allow Miss Mary Savage payment at the rate of $10 per teaching month for her services as janitor and the other work which she is called upon to perform. Payment at this rate will be made from October 1st, last. I have to request that you will prepare, at the end of each quarter, an account, in duplicate, for the amount of salary due Miss Mary Savage at the above rate. This should be certified by you in the usual manner and forwarded to the Department, when payment will be made. You should state on the voucher that it is in payment of her services as janitor and as assistant in the teaching of domestic science. Please inform Miss Savage of the amount that has been allowed her for these services.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Indian Agent,

Ottawa, July 14, 1931.

Sir:

Reverend Father Ryan, in a report on his inspection of the Indian Island Indian Day School, in June, last, states that the classroom is dark and should have another large-sized window installed, as, at the present time, there is only a small one at each end of the room. He states further that the door is poorly made and it will be necessary to have a new door installed before next winter. As you are aware, this is a rented building. Would it be possible to arrange with the owner to have this window installed and also a new door? If not, would she consent to the Department having this work done, the cost to be deducted from her rental? Please interview her at your early convenience and inform the Department, giving an estimate of the cost of any material and labour required.

Father Ryan also recommended that the outhouses be thoroughly cleaned, repaired and placed in a good condition. I have to request that you will have this work carried out during the present summer holidays. He further states that a pail, a broom and an axe are required, and you should arrange for the purchase and delivery of this equipment.

Father Ryan has drawn attention to the supplies required by the teachers of the Indian schools for their domestic science work. He states that several complained to him there was delay in receiving the necessary equipment. The teachers should anticipate their requirements and should prepare and forward to you requisition for transmission to the Department when authority will be given for you to purchase the articles considered necessary. After you receive the authority to make the purchase, you should give the matter prompt attention.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto,
N. B.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 14th instant File 55-6-5, re Indian Island Indian Day school, and in reply will say that the owner of the building is prepared to have a large sized window installed and the door replaced with a new one. This work will be done during the summer vacation.

The outhouses will be cleaned and any necessary repairs made before school opens after the summer holidays, and the broom, axe, and pail will be supplied.

In regard to the complaint of teachers about delay in receiving supplies I would say that they are not inconvenienced very much by any delay that has occurred. The teachers seem to think that as soon as they give me the requisition I should purchase the things immediately, and apparently they do not know that the Department has to be communicated with first. Of course there may have been some cases of delay on my part in purchasing after I had received your authority. I will be more careful in future.

Your obedient servant

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF REV. F. C. RYAN,
INSPECTOR OF INDIAN SCHOOLS FOR NEW BRUNSWICK,
ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE INDIAN ISLAND INDIAN DAY
SCHOOL ON JUNE 1st, 1937.

The building here used for a school belongs to
an Indian woman, Mrs. MacDonald. A partition so divided the
house as to give the teacher two rooms to live in, while the
other part is used for the schoolroom. This said partition
is so open that the cold from the schoolroom, when school is
not in session, makes it about impossible for the teacher to
heat her two rooms. She feels she cannot live this winter
in such conditions.

The Department will find in my Reports that I
have asked for two years to have this partition repaired.
It has not been done. I am sure $20 or less would do the
work. I trust it will be looked after during vacation.

In fact a new school building should be built,
with proper quarters for a teacher, as there is no place here
for a teacher to board.

Besides this school building, there is a shed
and two out houses which belong to the Government.

The closets require to be repaired, whitewashed,
etc.
Ottawa, June 24th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

In his report regarding his inspection of the Indian Island Indian Day School on the first instant, Inspector Ryan writes:

"The building here used for a school belongs to an Indian woman, Mrs. MacDonald. A partition so divided the house as to give the teacher two rooms to live in, while the other part is used for the schoolroom. This said partition is so open that the cold from the schoolroom, when school is not in session, makes it about impossible for the teacher to heat her two rooms. She feels she cannot live this winter in such conditions.

The Department will find in my Reports that I have asked for two years to have this partition repaired. It has not been done. I am sure $20 or less would do the work. I trust it will be looked after during vacation.

"The closets require to be repaired, whitewashed, etc."

If the repairs to the partition can be done at a cost not exceeding $20.00, you may proceed with the work.

You may, also, repair the toilets and have them whitewashed.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Chas. Hudson, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Richibucto, N. B."

Richibucto, N.B., May 12th, 1938.

Dear Sir:

With regard to the Indian Island day school, I would sooner wait until Mr. Phalen views the situation, as the building there is very small and probably the department would build a new one. The building there is rented from an Indian.

I would recommend that whatever work is to be done on these school buildings, should be commenced as soon as possible after the schools close for summer vacation.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. Hudson.

Ottawa, June 24, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to that portion of your letter of the 12th ultimo which mentions the Indian Island School.

As this is a rented building, the Department would hardly be justified in spending any large sum of money on it. At the same time, we have no funds available for the erection of a new building this year. If the owner of this building is obtaining $20.00 a month rent, it is felt that she should expend some money on it.

The question of providing funds in our next year's appropriation for a new building at this point will be discussed with you, if I have an opportunity of going to New Brunswick this Fall. If not, you should report fully about September 30th regarding the necessity for a school at this point.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

I have acknowledged the receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, enclosing one from Miss Frances McGinn, teacher of the Kingsclear School, replying to the remarks of the Department in regard to specimens of work done by pupils of her school.

In the matter of the drawings, the only reason for asking whether they were traced was the fact that some of them are so remarkably good that the idea of their being traced naturally suggested itself, and it is fortunate that the question was asked, otherwise the pupils would not have got credit for such excellent work. The two deer in the picture with the hippopotamus are particularly good.

With respect to the Department's criticism of the false etymology given for the word "testament", I may say that if in his little essay Mitchell Sappier had said that generally where the word "testament" is used in the Bible the real meaning is "covenant" no exception could have been taken, for such is the case; but it is distinctly incorrect to say that the word "testament signifies alliance or covenant" simply because in a figurative or inexact form of speech it is so used in the Bible. The Deputy Superintendent General:

I beg to call your attention the remarks of Mr. Public School Inspector Brown on the Kingsclear school, which is in charge of Miss M.C. Monaghan, who was appointed in January, 1902, at a salary of $300.

Mr. Brown says that she is a splendid teacher and is having great success. He considers her one of the best teachers in his whole field and on the occasion of his last inspection he was accompanied by the teacher of the nearest white school, in order that she might profit by seeing Miss Monaghan's methods and manner. He considers it a great pity that a teacher like Miss Monaghan is obliged to work for the same salary as some other teacher who may not achieve half the success and thinks that this should be remedied.

As a recognition of Miss Monaghan's long service and successful results, the Department would be justified in giving her a substantial increase, not less than $100 a year, as it is to its interests to retain the services of efficient and painstaking teachers.

Sir,

In reply to your letter No 118349/1 of December 11th, 1914, I beg to report as follows:

I visited the Central Kingsclear Band and investigated the charges made against the School teacher, Miss Rena A. Donahoe, and have to say that I could find no evidence to substantiate them. There are Twenty pupils on the roll, and an average attendance the last quarter of fifteen. The girls are taught sewing three times a week. Regarding the charges of cruelty and neglect I could find nothing specific, and the general charges were denied by Miss Donahoe and contradicted by the Rev. Father O'Keefe, the Spiritual adviser of the Band who expressed the opinion that if anything, Miss Donahoe was too lenient.

Miss Donahoe informed me that she had for personal reasons tendered her resignation to take effect the end of this month. As she has been teaching this School for more than six years I believe a change would be beneficial.

I have the honour to be,

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of December 6, File No. 58-2-1. I not that you contemplate closing the Kingsclear Indian Day School, in view of the fact that on September 26th, there were but two pupils at school when Inspector Ryan visited there. I do not wish to appear presumptuous, but I would feel that many details had been neglected, if I did not set before you the facts as I see them.

I wonder why the Department has waited all these years to close this school for the same conditions have existed over a period of years, i.e., that the people of this reserve are more industrious than the rest of my Indians. They go each fall to the State of Maine and pick potatoes and the families, including the children go with them and in a great many instances work in the potato fields. The money they make is used to clothe themselves and make it possible for the children to attend school without any assistance from the Department.

I have gone into this matter very thoroughly and would outline to you the attendance during the potato picking season in the Kingsclear School from 1927 until the present time.

1927. On September 12, school opened with 9 pupils. Pupils left at different times for potato fields and on September 30th, 6 pupils were enrolled. Full attendance of 13 on October 31st, continuing all school year. Inspector's visit October 17th, 7 pupils.

1928. September 2nd, school opened with 8 pupils. Gradually left and on September 17th, 5 pupils enrolled. Full attendance again on Oct. 16th continuing all school year. Inspector's visit October 8, 5 pupils present.

If I may take the liberty to comment, I think that under the circumstances, i.e., that the children do go away with their parents, that this is a very good record. I feel that I do understand the situation, when there is never a week, but I visit the schools and Kingsclear is without a doubt one of the best in every way. I have repeatedly written to Inspector Ryan asking him to stop at my office on his way through Fredericton, so that we might talk the matter over, but for reasons of his own, he has not done this and I do not hesitate to say that a person cannot know very much about conditions as they are when they are inspecting four schools lying some eighty miles apart in one day, between the hours of nine and four. Now what is the solution?

To close the school, how would we educate the children. To have the Indian children attend the white school is simply out of the question. It could not be done. Possibly our school at Kingsclear could be closed during the month of September. Possibility of teaching the month of August instead of September. IMPRESSIVE CLOSING EXERCISES ARE HELD

Other Indian Schools at Devon, Oromocto and Woodstock, This Morning.

The annual closing of the school of the Kingsclear Indian Reservation yesterday afternoon was marked by presentations to Miss Estelle O'Brian, teacher, who is resigning after eleven years of service. At the conclusion of the scheduled exercises, Miss O'Brian was presented with a fitted travelling bag by little Miles Tomah, a Grade I pupil of the school, on behalf of the pupils. Audrey Tomah read an address in connection with the presentation. Miss O'Brian was taken unaware by the presentation, but responded with fitting words of thanks. Miss O'Brian also received gifts from the staff of the district Indian agent's office and from a number of the Indian families of the band.

The closing exercises were attended by Rev. Father Harris, S.J., Mr. McCutcheon of Fredericton, District Indian Agent; Chief William Polches and members of the Indian band. Rev. Father Harris and Mr. McCutcheon made expressions of thanks and appreciation of the faithful and efficient service of Miss O'Brian during the past eleven years. The resigning teacher will be succeeded by Miss Rita McDade.

A programme of patriotic songs and demonstrations of teaching was presented by the pupils for meritorious work during the school year. Prizes for highest standing were presented to Audrey Tomah and Noreen Tomah. For best attendance went to Ernest Polches. The cash prizes were donated by Rev. Father Harris and presented by Mr. McCutcheon.

Closings of Indian schools at Devon, Oromocto and Woodstock took place this morning. Mrs. Harry A. McElligott, teacher at the Devon Indian School, supervised the exercises.

Dear Sir:

On December 26th, the Christmas closings of our Indian Schools were held. The pupils exhibited handicraft work. The girls wore knitted sweaters.

The closing of the Oromocto Indian school was held in the morning. Of the 44 pupils enrolled, there was only one case of illness. The parents and friends of the pupils were present. A very enjoyable and interesting programme was carried out. Billy Brooks, one of the Grade 8 pupils conducted the exercises. There was a display of knitting by the girls. Many of them wore the sweaters they knit in school. Also hand work of the boys was exhibited, consisting of bookcases, table, book ends, tie racks, pen trays, etc. The Christmas decorations and drawings on the blackboards were done by Mary Paul and Josephine Paul and Teddy Brooks, were very much admired. At the close of the programme, treats or candy, etc., were distributed to each child from a beautifully decorated tree. Pupils making perfect attendance were, Rebecca Paul, Mildred Paul, Donald Paul, Jean Paul, Norman Wiseman, Albert Wiseman and Warren Scoote. The entertainment concluded with the singing of "There'll always be an England and God Save the King."

AT THE OROMOCOTO SCHOOL.

Miss Delphine Murray, teacher of the Indian School, Oromocto Reserve bids farewell to her pupils at the Christmas closing. The closing programme consisted of a review of the term's work. An exhibition of creditable knitting and hand work. A treat of candy, etc., was given each child. This was supplied by the Women's Catholic League of Oromocto.

AT THE KINGSCLEAR SCHOOL.

The Kingsclear Indian Reserve School had their Christmas closing in the afternoon with all the parents of the
The pupils were in attendance as well as many persons from the surrounding district. The school which was decorated by the pupils was in line with the Christmas spirit. Reverend Father Harris, Parish Priest of Kingsclear gave the prizes and presents which were presented by me. The programme was carried out under the supervision of Miss Rita McVade, the teacher. Faye Tomah and Clarence Tomah were the school leaders with first and second respectively. Perfect attendance certificates were awarded Edith Polchies and Ernest Polchies.

AT WOODSTOCK SCHOOL.

The Woodstock Indian School had their closing in the morning with all the pupils in attendance and many of the parents as well as the Sisters from Saint Gertrude's Convent, Woodstock. The programme which consisted of a playlet, was carried out under the supervision of Sister Delorosa and Sister Milliana. The school which was beautifully decorated gave a delightful Christmas effect. A large Christmas tree was much in evidence and from it Santa Claus distributed gifts to the pupils. During the programme there was an exhibition of handicraft and knitting by the pupils. Respectfully submitted.

The closing exercises of the Woodstock Indian day school with principal Rev. Sister Dolorosa and assistant, Rev. Sister Emiliana, were held on Friday morning June 27th. Prizes were presented and pupils addressed by Mr. MacCutcheon, who congratulated them on the year's work and encouraged them to keep up their good standards and expressed deep satisfaction with the work of the Sisters, not only in the school, but among the girls and families of the Reservation.

Attention Mr. Phelan.
Re-School Teacher Kingsclear Indian Day School.

Dear Sir:

Miss Rita McDade, teacher of the Kingsclear Indian Day School informed me October 9th, that it was her intention to resign. The resignation to take effect November 20th.

Father Harris and I tried to find another teacher to take her place but without success. Owing to our difficulties Miss McDade consented to finish the present term.

I have not as yet, received an official resignation, although I have asked Miss McDade to submit one soon.

To date, we have not been able to locate a teacher with the necessary qualifications. I have had three applications from second class teachers. All have had three years experience in rural districts.

Teachers are very scarce, in fact there is a shortage in New Brunswick; and the Department of Education has granted local license in different cases where the district was unable to obtain the services of a licensed teacher.

Father Harris and I are still making enquiries regarding a teacher, and we feel that a suitable one will be located in time. However, if we should fail, would it be in order to accept an application from a second class teacher.

Your obedient Servant,

Acting Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

No doubt by this time you have received the resignation of Miss Rita McDade, teacher in the Indian school here at Kingsclear.

I did not think a little over a year ago when I appealed to you for the appointment of Miss McDade to succeed Miss O'Brien that I would have to call on you so soon, but Miss McDade has decided to join the ranks of the benedicts and so has sent in her resignation as teacher of the Indian school.

At present in the Province of New Brunswick there is a great scarcity of teachers and according to statistics there are some 70 schools without any teachers at all. Considering that condition, would it be possible to have Mrs. Lloyd Edwards, formerly Miss Stella O'Brien, who is still living in this Parish appointed to the school to finish out the present school year. In that case before the opening of the next school year we would be able to find a suitable teacher according to the requirements that you gave me when I visited you in your office over a year ago. I have spoken to the Liberal Committee here in York County and also to Mr. Peter Hughes of the Federal Committee, and they are both agreeable to the appointment of Mrs. Edwards until June.

I think that you understand my position here and you must realize that I have at heart not only the education of the children in temporal things, but also the religious welfare of the children as well, and it would be to my mind a much better arrangement to have Mrs. Edwards appointed temporarily and thus give us time to find a suitable teacher for a permanent appointment for the next school year. May I hope to hear from you regarding this matter.

I had hoped to see you, but no doubt the pressure of business kept you from touring our part of the country this year. I wish to renew again our friendship and to send you my kind personal regards.

I remain,

Yours very truly,
